awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Deciphering Design Principles of Early Embryonic Cell Cycles
awd_abstract_narration:
Biological clocks are genetically controlled processes that allow organisms to anticipate environmental changes, which are central to developmental biology. This project will develop a synthetic biology framework to reveal quantitative information on clock cycles and how this cycle influences cellular architecture. The project will use this framework to address how the mitotic clock is designed to achieve robust cell cycles in young embryonic zebrafish cells. Given that biological clocks exist ubiquitously in organisms from bacteria to humans this project will provide insights into developmental biology and diseases, including cancer. This highly interdisciplinary research will serve as a training resource for K-12, undergraduate and graduate students to gain experience in theoretical modeling, optical imaging, nanofabrication, developmental biology, data analysis and scientific communication. Outreach activities will include demonstrations at museums and lab open days developed in collaboration with local professional educators.

The goal of this project is to establish a synthetic biology approach to decipher the fundamental design principles of a mitotic circuit that drives early cell cycles in zebrafish embryos. This project will develop a cell-free system, build artificial cells to reconstitute mitotic events that resemble the processes of early embryonic cell divisions, and develop novel single-cell imaging and tracking systems. The results in the cell-free system will be tested in live embryos to assess their biological relevance. The objectives of this project are to: 1) establish computational methods and search for all robust and tunable oscillation topologies, 2) artificially construct mitotic cells and examine its topology for functions of robustness and tunability, and 3) combine in vitro and in vivo studies to evaluate the role of mitotic clocks in live zebrafish embryos. The findings may be generalizable to a wide spectrum of biological clocks that share similar core architecture with the mitotic clock.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This NSF award, aiming to elucidate the design principles that drive the synchronous, rapid, reductive cleavages in the first several divisions of early embryos, has supported projects that led to 15 publications in various journals (Analytical Chemistry, Biomicrofluidics, Cell Systems, eLife, JoVE, PNAS, etc.) 

 

The key outcomes of the intellectual merit are as follows. We have developed a computational framework to generate a comprehensive mapping from the topology space to the function space, which allows the identification of simple universal rules independent of any chosen systems. Applying this framework, we have identified the three most robust cores that coincide with those found in natural and synthetic oscillators (i.e., the classic Goodwin, repressilator, activator-repressor oscillators), confirming our method’s effectiveness. Moreover, it led to a striking discovery, ‘incoherent inputs’, a simple rule to modify any node and enhance the overall performance of the whole system. The rule unifies the conflicting results in the literature and functions in larger-scale networks and experimentally validated systems, suggesting that it can be a general mechanism. To reconstitute and analyze oscillation functions of topology, we have also developed a microfluidic approach to encapsulate the cell-free extracts in water-in-oil microemulsion droplets. These droplet cells can mimic dynamic processes of the cell cycle just like living cells. Moreover, these cells give us great flexibility to manipulate the clock topology, oscillation speed, and cell size across wide dynamic ranges, which would otherwise be difficult in real cells or live embryos. It allows us to study many fascinating questions that would otherwise be hard to answer in living organisms. 

 

The outcomes of the broader impact of this award include both educational and outreach activities. A few highlights are that we have prioritized research opportunities for the retention of diverse, introductory, and underrepresented students in STEM, through various programs (e.g., UROP, REU, PREP, MHSURA). We have also developed a low-cost (~$100) handheld device (µdroPi) and demonstrated how it could be used for imaging and performing high-throughput droplet generation and analysis in general labs. It allows the dissemination of state-of-art technology to the broader scientific community and education in a typical college laboratory course. We have developed table-top demos on biological clocks to the general public at the Scientist Spotlight Program, Science Communication Fellows Program, and Dinosaur Discovery Day at the Museum of Natural History. My lab also gave Science for Tomorrow program (SFT) workshop to underserved middle school students from several Detroit schools.

 


Last Modified: 02/08/2022
Modified by: Qiong Yang
